edge: The film explores the life of a dyslexic child named Ishaan, making Taare Zameen Par and dyslexic related concepts.
Ishaan's poor academic performance leads his parents to send him to a boarding school, where a new art teacher Nikumbh suspects that he is dyslexic and helps him overcome his reading disorder.
Aamir Khan plays the role of Nikumbh, a new art teacher who suspects that Ishaan is dyslexic and helps him overcome his reading disorder.
Darsheel Safary plays the role of Ishaan, a dyslexic child whose poor academic performance leads his parents to send him to a boarding school.
Shankar–Ehsaan–Loy composed the score for Taare Zameen Par.
Prasoon Joshi wrote the lyrics for many of the songs in Taare Zameen Par.
The film helped raise awareness about dyslexia, making it related to dyslexic children and Taare Zameen Par.

Ram demonstrates to Maya and Yohaan how Ishaan has extreme difficulty in understanding letters and words due to dyslexia, and his poverty in sports skills stems from his poor motor ability (which also applies to his difficulty in tying shoelaces and judging the size, speed, and distance of a ball)
Ram brings up the topic of dyslexia in a class and offers a list of famous dyslexic people. Ram comforts Ishaan and shares that he struggled with dyslexia as a child.
Ram becomes Ishaan's tutor to improve his reading and writing skills using remedial techniques developed by dyslexia specialists.

Ram comforts Ishaan when discussing dyslexia in a class and becomes his tutor to improve his reading and writing skills using remedial techniques developed by dyslexia specialists.
Ram organises an arts and crafts contest for the staff and students, judged by artist Lalita Lajmi.
The principal announces that Ram has been hired as the Boarding School's Permanent Art Teacher and Ishaan wins an arts and crafts contest.
Nandkishore thanks Ram for transforming Ishaan after meeting him on the last day of school and sees Ishaan attempting to read from a board, leaving him teary-eyed.
Ram paints Ishaan's portrait in an arts and crafts contest, with Ram as the runner-up.

The husband and wife team of Amole Gupte and Deepa Bhatia developed the story that eventually became Taare Zameen Par as a way of understanding why some children could not conform to a conventional educational system due to dyslexia. Their research led them to explore possible reasons for this and their work began as a short story that evolved into a screenplay over seven years.

node_2: characters and situations in the film
edge: Bhatia and Gupte worked with dyslexic children to research and develop the screenplay, basing characters and situations on their observations. They carefully concealed the children's identities in the final version of the script.

Bhatia and Gupte explored some possible reasons why dyslexic children failed in school by doing research with the Maharashtra Dyslexia Association while developing the character of a young boy based on Japanese filmmaker Akira Kurosawa.
Bhatia and Gupte also did research with Parents for a Better Curriculum for the Child (PACE) while developing the character of a young boy based on Japanese filmmaker Akira Kurosawa.

node_2: original inspiration for how a teacher could transform the life of a student
edge: Deepa Bhatia cited a specific place in Kurosawa's biography where he began to excel after meeting an attentive art teacher, and said that it 'became the inspiration for how a teacher could transform the life of a student'.

Khan and Gupte first met in college. Khan admired Gupte's abilities as an actor, writer, and painter before three years of the film's release. Gupte brought Khan to the project as a producer and actor, but Khan lost faith in Gupte's directing abilities during the film's shooting. However, Gupte convinced Khan to stay on board by stepping down as director. There were creative differences between the two, leading Khan to claim that he was the director of the film after its wrap-up party.

Khan took over the role of director for Taare Zameen Par, as he wanted to prevent any delay in production due to hiring a third party. The character Ishaan might have aged too much for the part had production been delayed.

The soundtrack for Taare Zameen Par was released under the label T-Series by Indian trade website Box Office India, selling around 1,100,000 units and becoming the year's thirteenth highest-selling.
The soundtrack for Taare Zameen Par was released under the label T-Series by Indian trade website Box Office India, selling around 1,100,000 units and becoming the year's thirteenth highest-selling.

The song 'Maa' from Taare Zameen Par has lyrics by Prasoon Joshi, who received the National Film Award for Best Lyrics.
Within the first three days, Taare Zameen Par grossed ₹150 million (US$3.63 million) domestically.
Taare Zameen Par completed its domestic run with $19,779,215.
Taare Zameen Par was released worldwide on 14 December 2007.

The Maharashtra government granted the film exemption from the entertainment tax.
The theatre occupancy in Mumbai dropped to 58 percent during its third week, but climbed back to 62 percent the following week.
Anticipating further tax exemption in other states, world distributor PVR Pictures circulated 200 more prints of the film.
Reports regarding the film's worldwide gross have conflicted.

Taare Zameen Par received widespread critical acclaim upon release.
According to review aggregator website Rotten Tomatoes, 93% of 14 critics' reviews for Taare Zameen Par are positive.
On the review aggregator website Rotten Tomatoes, Taare Zameen Par has an average rating of 7.4/10.
Subhash K. Jha suggests that Aamir Khan holds back where he could easily resort to an extravagant display of drama and emotions in Taare Zameen Par.
According to Subhash K. Jha, Taare Zameen Par is 'a work of art'.
Subhash K. Jha suggests that the colors in Taare Zameen Par drip into our hearts, making it a 'water painting where the colors drip into our hearts'.

According to Rajeev Masand, CNN-IBN, Taare Zameen Par's true power lies in its 'remarkable, rooted, rock-solid script which provides the landscape for such an emotionally engaging, heart-warming experience.'
According to Manish Gajjar of the BBC, Taare Zameen Par 'touches your heart and moves you deeply with its sterling performances. [It is] a film full of substance!'

According to Jaspreet Pandohar, also of BBC, Taare Zameen Par is a 'far cry from the formulaic masala flicks churned out by the Bollywood machine' and is 'an inspirational story that is as emotive as it is entertaining; this is a little twinkling star of a movie.'

Anurag Kashyap, a filmmaker, shared his emotions after watching the movie 'Taare Zameen Par'. The impact of the movie left him speechless, and he could not express how much he liked it. This shows that the movie had an intense and powerful effect on him.

The plot of 'Taare Zameen Par' revolves around a dyslexic child, and Anurag Kashyap mentioned that if the condition of dyslexia was not present in the movie, it would have been similar to his own story from his college days.
The statement 'because the 'perfectionist' actor has shaped into a 'perfectionist' director' highlights that the movie's director, Aamir Khan, is also known for his perfectionism as an actor.
The statement 'very rarely do performances get so gripping' signifies that the performances in the movie 'Taare Zameen Par' are exceptionally captivating and engaging.

In his article 'Taare Zameen Par and dyslexic savants', Ambar Chakravarty noted that the portrayal of Ishaan's dyslexia in the movie was generally accurate. However, he found it puzzling that Ishaan had trouble with simple arithmetic, which is a trait of dyscalculia rather than dyslexia, but reasoned that this was meant to 'enhance the image of [Ishaan's] helplessness and disability'. Chakravarty labeled Ishaan an example of 'dyslexic savant syndrome' and especially praised the growth of Ishaan's artistic talents after receiving help and support from Nikumbh, which he deemed the 'most important (and joyous) neurocognitive phenomenon' of the film.

Labeling Ishaan an example of 'dyslexic savant syndrome', Ambar Chakravarty highlighted the issue of cosmetic neurology, which is a 'major and therapeutically important issue' in cognitive neuroscience and neuropsychology. The improvement in Ishaan's artistic talents after receiving help and support from Nikumbh is an example of this phenomenon.

the film raises serious questions on mental health perspectives and explores how threats and coercion are not capable of unearthing rich human potentialities deeply embedded in children, while teachers should instead map their strengths and weaknesses. The authors believe that the film depicts how teachers should focus on getting to know the child before making any efforts to fill them with knowledge and abilities, and Khan 'dexterously drives home the precise point that our first priority ought to be getting to know the child before making any efforts to fill them with knowledge and abilities'. Overall, the authors found a 'naive oversimplification' in the film and believed that it expands beyond disabilities and explores the 'present age where everyone is in a restless hurry'. The pair wrote that the film deserves to be vastly appreciated as an earnest endeavor to portray with sensitivity and empathetically diagnose a malady in human life, and blends'modern professional knowledge' with a 'humane approach' in working with a dyslexic child. The authors also believed that the film expands beyond disabilities and explores the 'present age where everyone is in a restless hurry', and that it raises serious questions on mental health perspectives. They further wrote, 'This film raises serious questions on mental health perspectives. We seem to be heading to a state of mass scale mindlessness even as children are being pushed to 'perform'.'

the authors felt that Khan 'dexterously drives home the precise point that our first priority ought to be getting to know the child before making any efforts to fill them with knowledge and abilities'. They further believed that the film depicts how 'threats and coercion are not capable of unearthing rich human potentialities deeply embedded in children', and that teachers should instead map their strengths and weaknesses. With this in mind, the author felt that Khan 'dexterously drives home the precise point that our first priority ought to be getting to know the child before making any efforts to fill them with knowledge and abilities'. They also believed that the film depicts how 'threats and coercion are not capable of unearthing rich human potentialities deeply embedded in children', and that teachers should instead map their strengths and weaknesses.
Overall, the pair found a 'naive oversimplification' in the film regarding learning disabilities.
They easily [forgave the film's fault] under artistic license considering India 'only recently waking to recognizing the reality and tragedy of learning disability'.

Gupte received painful letters and phone calls from Indian parents after the film's release.
Fathers weep on the phone and say they saw the film and realized that they have been wrong in the way they treated their children. This is catharsis.
The Central Board of Secondary Education provided extra time to disabled children—including visually impaired, physically disabled, and dyslexic students—during exams following the film's release.
Following the film's release, Mumbai's civic body opened 12 classrooms for autistic students.
Following the film's release, the education administration in Chandigarh started a course to educate teachers on how to support children with learning disabilities.

The film has had a similarly positive response in Greater China, where it was not officially released yet has a large online cult following due to Aamir Khan's popularity in the region after the success of 3 Idiots (2009).
The film has been well received by Chinese audiences for how it tackles issues such as education and dyslexia,

The Indian news media frequently compared Taare Zameen Par's nomination failure with Slumdog Millionaire's multiple Academy Award nominations and wins, due to the former being overlooked in the past and the latter being marketed in a way that Indian films could not compete with. Film critic Rajeev Masand argued that it is difficult to compare the two films.

Actor Mahesh Manjrekar stated that while he thought Taare Zameen Par was way better than Slumdog Millionaire, he did not mean to take anything away from the film's director Danny Boyle and its child actors.
